Re: License #: CB250201474
Dear Mr. Perlaki:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
9/2/2025. The inspection has determined substantial compliance with applicable licensing
statutes and rules.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at 616-204-6992.
Sincerely,
Lonia Perry Calloway, Licensing Consultant

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• There was no technical assistance requested or required.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• R400.12510(2) Independent living agreement: the agency was advised
consistently completing the independent living agreement with the youth at the
time of the service plan, as it had in some cases, may aid it in showing ongoing
compliance to the rule.
VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has not been required to submit any corrective action plans during
this period under review.
2

Chief Administrator Assessment
The agency submitted a chief administrator's report dated 9/2/2025. The agency
had no rule violations during its 2024 Renewal inspection and so no corrective
action plan was required. In this 2025 chief administrator’s (CA)report the CA
reported on the number of disruptions the agency experienced and some reasons
for those disruptions. The CA also indicated what the agency assessed as its
strengths and challenges. The former included the agency being the only program
in the community to serve non-system homeless youth age 16 and up; and the
multiple opportunities it offers to youths to challenge themselves and learn new
skills. In terms of the latter, it indicated it greatest challenge is the recruitment and
retention of qualified staff after seasoned staff leaves. The CA reported the
remaining staff have aided in this area by working overtime.
Financial Overview
The agency provided a copy of its 2024/2025 annual budget; and 9/30/2024,
independent financial audit. A review of these documents did not show any areas
of concern.
Staff Interviews
In addition to a discussion with the chief administrator and a case manager, I
interviewed a youth specialist. The staff members reported positives about the
program, which included that the administration listens to staff ideas, the agency
staff all work together as a team; and they provide and encourage the youths.
Area of growth indicated were for the program’s intake to increase; and for new
workers to be more mature.
Description of Agency Walk Through
During my walk through of the facility, no areas of concern or safety issues were
observed. Staff and youths have sufficient space and supplies to meet their
needs; and youth files were safely stored.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
This agency is not contracted with the Michigan Department of Health and Human
Services (MDHHS) to provide foster care placement or certification services;
therefore, this is not applicable.
3

VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the agency continue on their
regular license.
September 18, 2025
________________________________________
Lonia Perry Calloway Date
